Granting Access Rights at the Project Level

Project-level settings define access rights for all views, child folders, and items in the project. A user will not be able to open a project if you deny any of the following to a user or to all the groups to which the user belongs:

  • The ability to see the project.

  • The ability to see the initial (or root) view of the project.

  • The ability to see the project’s initial view’s root folder.

The only level at which you can set project access rights is at the project level, because this is the only level that has a Project node in the access rights hierarchy. You can set view access rights at either the project or view level, because both of those levels have the View node. You can set folder access rights at the project, view, or folder levels, and so on.

It is critically important to define a complete set of project-level access rights for all groups with view rights to a project. By default, groups with view rights have complete access to categories that have no rights defined. Therefore, Borland recommends that you specify access rights across all project rights for all groups.

General Rule

Any time you create one grant record for a node, you should also create a grant record for that node for every group that will access the project at this level. It is also a good idea to include Administrators on each node. Then if permissions are ignored, an administrator can still change access rights, etc.

To set project access rights:

  1. Open the project.

  2. Select Project > Access Rights from the StarTeam client menu. This action displays the Project Access Rights dialog.

  3. Select a node. It is best to start with the Project node and work down.

  4. Click Add to add a user or group. The Assign Access Rights To dialog opens.

  5. Select a user or group. Users are listed by their user names and groups are listed by their position in the group hierarchy, except for the All Users group.

  6. Select the Grant option button. Note: Never select the Deny option button unless you are creating an exception. See Setting Access Rights Exceptions.

  7. Click OK to return to the Project Access Rights dialog.

  8. Select and/or clear the appropriate check boxes for the user or group.

  9. Repeat steps 3-8, as required.

  10. Click OK when you are done.

Project Access Rights

See object and its properties

See this project in the projects list, and view its properties by selecting Project > Properties.

Modify properties

Change the properties for this project. The project properties that can be modified are its name, description, the keyword expansions settings, the settings for alternate property editors (APEs), the setting for process rules, and the settings that require revision comments, file check-ins only with exclusive locks, and unlocked files to be read-only.

Delete object

Delete this project from its server configuration.

Change object access rights

Change the access rights for this project. If you change this setting, be sure that you remain one of the users who can change access rights.
